photo.description: Third Order Fresnel Bivalve Lamp
photo.tags: fresnel lakesuperior lighthouses minnesota rock shoreline greatlakes light splitrock tower
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse

photo.description: This year marks the 100th year of the first lighting of Split Rock Lighthouse. As part of the celebration, the Minnesota Historical Society has been lighting it for an hour or two on the first Friday of each month. I was fortunate enough to be able to be there for the November lighting. I have to say, seeing the lighthouse lit up is absolutely spectacular and worth it if you ever get the chance. This photo shows a closeup of the spectacular fresnel lens of this lighthouse. It is a third order lens, and is the original lens that was installed when the lighthouse was built. It is a bivalve type lens with two flash panels and it rotates, producing a flash every 12 seconds. The lens itself floats on a pool of 7 1/2 quarts of mercury. It was originally rotated by a clockworks mechanism that is driven by a counterweight that drops down a column in the center of the tower. The weight has to be wound back to the top of the tower ever few hours. The clockworks was discontinued in the 1940s when the light was electrified, but in the 1980s it was restored and is now used again to turn the lens. The lens is currently lit by a 1000 watt incandescent light bulb.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse fresnel northshore lakesuperior mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse - Celebrating 100 Years

photo.description: This year marks the 100th year of the first lighting of Split Rock Lighthouse. As part of the celebration, the Minnesota Historical Society has been lighting it for an hour or two on the first Friday of each month. I was fortunate enough to be able to be there for the November lighting. I have to say, seeing the lighthouse lit up is absolutely spectacular and worth it if you ever get the chance. This photo shows a closeup of the spectacular fresnel lens of this lighthouse. It is a third order lens, and is the original lens that was installed when the lighthouse was built. It is a bivalve type lens with two flash panels and it rotates, producing a flash every 12 seconds. The lens itself floats on a pool of 7 1/2 quarts of mercury. It was originally rotated by a clockworks mechanism that is driven by a counterweight that drops down a column in the center of the tower. The weight has to be wound back to the top of the tower ever few hours. photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse - Celebrating 100 Years

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse was equipped with a 3rd order, bi-valve type Fresnel lens that was manufactured by Barbier, Bernard and Turenne Company in Paris, France. It is a combination of glass prisms and a brass framework. Although extremely heavy, the lens floats on a bearing surface of liquid mercury. This magnificent lens is almost 100 years old and is the original lens. You are looking up into the lens through an opening in the base that was originally used to light the incandescent vapor lamp.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse fresnel lens prism brass lighthouse mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse: The Beautiful Lens

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse as seen from the shore of Lake Superior
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse

photo.description: Looking inside of the 3rd order fresnel lens at Split Rock Lighthouse. The light source was originally an incandescent oil vapor lamp that burned kerosene. In 1940, the station was electrified, and the oil lamp was replaced with a 1000 watt electric light bulb, which is what is pictured here.
photo.tags: lighthouse splitrock twoharbors mn usa fresnel lightbulb prism glass uslhs splitrocklighthouse
photo.title: Let there be light!

photo.description: Split Rock is unusual in that the clockworks that was originally used to rotate the giant lens is not only still in existence, but it has also been restored and continues to rotate the lens today. Clockworks are like a giant grandfather clock. A counterweight drops down the center of the tower and causes the clocksworks to spin, which causes the lens to turn. This is a closeup of some of the gears within the clockworks.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse northshore lakesuperior minnesotahistoricalsociety mhs mn usa
photo.title: North Shore Trip - Fall 2012 - Split Rock Clockworks

photo.tags: lakesuperior lighthouse photostream iphoto duluth splitrocklighthouse

photo.description: The classic view of the wonderful lighthouse
photo.title: Split Rock

photo.description: This year marks the 100th year of the first lighting of Split Rock Lighthouse. As part of the celebration, the Minnesota Historical Society has been lighting it for an hour or two on the first Friday of each month. I was fortunate enough to be able to be there for the November lighting. I have to say, seeing the lighthouse lit up is absolutely spectacular and worth it if you ever get the chance. This photo shows a closeup of the spectacular fresnel lens of this lighthouse. It is a third order lens, and is the original lens that was installed when the lighthouse was built. It is a bivalve type lens with two flash panels and it rotates, producing a flash every 12 seconds. The lens itself floats on a pool of 7 1/2 quarts of mercury. It was originally rotated by a clockworks mechanism that is driven by a counterweight that drops down a column in the center of the tower. The weight has to be wound back to the top of the tower ever few hours. The clockworks was discontinued in the 1940s when the light was electrified, but in the 1980s it was restored and is now used again to turn the lens. The lens is currently lit by a 1000 watt incandescent light bulb. This photo shows a MHS employee dressed as a lighthouse keeper walking past the lens to give you an idea of the scale of the lens.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse fresnel northshore lakesuperior mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse - Celebrating 100 Years

photo.description: On my way back home from the cabin I stopped at Split Rock Lighthouse -- one of my favorite places to visit. This year, the lighthouse celebrates 100 years of watching over the shores of Lake Superior. It is known as one of the most visited lighthouses in the world, and this day was no exception, as you can see by the photo.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse mhs lakesuperior northshore mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse Celebrates 100 Years

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse was equipped with a 3rd order, bi-valve type Fresnel lens that was manufactured by Barbier, Bernard and Turenne Company in Paris, France. It is a combination of glass prisms and a brass framework. Although extremely heavy, the lens floats on a bearing surface of liquid mercury. This magnificent lens is almost 100 years old and is the original lens. This photo shows a close-up of one of the bulls-eye panels that focuses the light into an extremely strong beam. You are looking up into the lens through an opening in the base that was originally used to light the incandescent vapor lamp.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse fresnel lens prism brass lighthouse mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse: The Beautiful Lens

You are looking up into the lens through an opening in the base that was originally used to light the incandescent vapor lamp.

photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse: The Beautiful Lens

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse was equipped with a 3rd order, bi-valve type Fresnel lens that was manufactured by Barbier, Bernard and Turenne Company in Paris, France. It is a combination of glass prisms and a brass framework. Although extremely heavy, the lens floats on a bearing surface of liquid mercury. This magnificent lens is almost 100 years old and is the original lens. This photo shows a close-up of the electric light that powers the lighthouse now. It is a single 1000 watt lightbulb. You are looking up into the lens through an opening in the base that was originally used to light the incandescent vapor lamp.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse fresnel lens prism brass lighthouse mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse: The Electric Lamp

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse was equipped with a 3rd order, bi-valve type Fresnel lens that was manufactured by Barbier, Bernard and Turenne Company in Paris, France. It is a combination of glass prisms and a brass framework. Although extremely heavy, the lens floats on a bearing surface of liquid mercury. This magnificent lens is almost 100 years old and is the original lens. This photo shows a close-up of one of the panels that surrounds the bullseye. You are looking up into the lens through an opening in the base that was originally used to light the incandescent vapor lamp.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse fresnel lens prism brass lighthouse twoharbors mn usa
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse: The Beautiful Lens

photo.description: I visited Two Harbors, MN this past weekend and got to do all kinds of fun things. I haven't had time to process all of my photos, but I thought this might be a good teaser. This is the fresnel lens from the Split Rock Lighthouse, as seen looking up in to the lens itself. Those are glass prisms held in place by a brass frame. It is nearly 100 years old. Many more photos to come. Enjoy!
photo.title: A Teaser....

photo.description: This is my favorite place in the world -- Split Rock Lighthouse State Park. This photo was taken on the walking trail that leads from the cliff face to the water's edge.
photo.tags: mn minnesota lighthouses splitrock lighthouse splitrocklighthouse
photo.title: Split Rock Through The Trees

photo.description: Split Rock Lighthouse near Two Harbors, MN was (and still is) equipped with a 3rd order, bi-valve type fresnel lens when it was originally built in 1909. That lens is still in place. This massive collection of glass prisms mounted in a brass framework is rotated with a clockworks and counterweight system. The source of light is placed right in the center of the lens. Originally the light source was an incandescent oil vapor lamp that burned kerosene. In 1940, it was electrified and the oil vapor lamp was replaced with a 1000 electric light bulb. The official range of this light was 22 miles. This photo was taken from the watchroom level of the tower, one level below the lantern. The watchroom level is where the clockworks is housed.
photo.tags: lighthouse splitrock fresnel bivalve twoharbors mn usa splitrocklighthouse
photo.title: The Great Eye at Split Rock Light

photo.description: Split Rock Light Station was equipped with a foghorn. The original was an air siren powered by twin gasoline motors. Around WWII they replaced it with a diaphone type foghorn (the type that goes Beee Ooooh!) which powered the compressors with diesel engines. The compressors and engines are no longer there, but the horns on the top of the fog signal building are.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse twoharbors mn usa foghorn
photo.title: Beeeeeeeeeeeeeee Ooooooooooooooh!

photo.description: A classic vantage point of Split Rock. This photo is taken from the beach at the landing where the original tramway ended on the shore of Lake Superior. That cliff is 160 feet tall. Just think -- at the time this lighthouse was built, the only way to get stuff to the top of that cliff was lift it using a steam derrick.
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse -- From the Tramway Beach

photo.description: Through the trees and the late afternoon sun, you get a glimpse of the massive 3rd order bi-valve type fresnel lens that this lighthouse was equipped with when it was built. Most lighhouses no longer have their original glass lens and very few used this bi-valve type.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse twoharbors mn usa fresnel lens
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse -- Through the Trees

photo.description: On the desk of the head light keeper at Split Rock Lighthouse
photo.tags: uslhs splitrocklighthouse lighthouse twoharbors mn usa
photo.title: Light Keeper's Office

photo.description: A classic vantage point of Split Rock. This photo is taken from the beach at the landing where the original tramway ended on the shore of Lake Superior. That cliff is 160 feet tall. Just think -- at the time this lighthouse was built, the only way to get stuff to the top of that cliff was lift it using a steam derrick.
photo.title: Split Rock Lighthouse -- From the Tramway Beach

photo.description: The massive lens at Split Rock is still rotated by a clockworks mechanism, which is pictured here. This mechanism is turned by the weight of a 240 pound counterweight that drops down the center of the tower. Most lighthouses no longer use this type of mechanism, and have since resorted to electric motors to turn the lens.
photo.tags: splitrocklighthouse lighthouse twoharbors mn usa clockworks minnesotahistoricalsociety
photo.title: It's a giant grandfather clock!

photo.description: Seen from the Split Rock Lighthouse
photo.title: Lake Superior
